scenario.setup: Attorney makes a vague request without specifics.

messages.content: I need to learn employment law.

expected: Asks clarifying questions about why, what aspects, and timeline
Does not produce a curriculum without understanding the scope and urgency
Helps the attorney narrow the topic to something learnable

conversation.content: I need to learn employment law.

Before I build you a curriculum, I need to understand your situation better so I can make this actually useful rather than generic.

A few quick questions:

**1. What's driving this?**
- New client matter landing on your desk?
- Thinking about adding employment to your practice?
- Lateral move or firm expansion?
- Something specific happened (e.g., a client just got sued)?

**2. Which side of employment law?**
This is a big field with distinct practice tracks:
- **Employer-side** (defending companies in litigation, advising HR, drafting policies)
- **Employee-side** (plaintiff's work — discrimination, wage/hour, wrongful termination)
- **Transactional/compliance** (employment aspects of M&A, executive comp, handbooks, restrictive covenants)
- **Government/regulatory** (NLRB, EEOC, DOL enforcement)

These overlap but require different skill sets and resources.

**3. What's your timeline?**
- Days (client meeting next week)?
- Weeks (new matter, need to get competent fast)?
- Months (deliberate practice area build)?

**4. What's your baseline?**
- Completely new — haven't touched it since law school?
- Some exposure from adjacent work (e.g., you've handled employment clauses in M&A deals, or defended a single EEOC charge)?
- Familiar with the basics but need to go deeper in a specific area?

**5. Jurisdiction?**
Federal law is the floor, but state employment law varies enormously — California, New York, and Illinois, for example, are dramatically more employee-friendly than federal law and have their own compliance regimes. If you're in a specific state, that shapes the curriculum significantly.

---

The more specific you can be, the more targeted I can make this. Even a sentence or two on each of these gets me most of the way there.

structural.description: Agent asks about the topic, timeline, baseline knowledge, and reason for learning
structural.justification: The agent explicitly asks about all four criteria—topic specificity (which side of employment law, jurisdiction), reason for learning (what's driving this), timeline (days/weeks/months), and baseline knowledge—before building any curriculum.

structural.description: Agent identifies the essential elements of competence in the target area
structural.justification: The agent asks clarifying questions before presenting any curriculum, but does not identify or name the essential elements of competence in employment law (key concepts, governing sources, or practical skills) prior to doing so.

structural.description: Curriculum is organized into Foundation, Depth, Practice, and Currency phases
structural.justification: The agent has not yet provided any curriculum at all — it is still gathering information through diagnostic questions, so there are no phases or stages to evaluate.

structural.description: Each recommended resource includes a description, rationale, and priority level
structural.justification: The agent has not yet recommended any resources in this response, so there are no resources to evaluate against the criterion of including descriptions, rationales, and priority levels.

structural.description: Output is a structured document with learning goal, phases, time estimates, and sequence
structural.justification: The agent has not yet produced any curriculum document; it only asked clarifying questions and has not provided a structured output with learning goals, phases, time estimates, or sequenced resources.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum respects the attorney's limited time and prioritizes high-impact resources
pedagogical.justification: Before investing any time in curriculum-building, the agent efficiently gathers the five key variables (urgency, practice track, timeline, baseline, jurisdiction) that would most dramatically affect what resources to prioritize, avoiding the waste of delivering a generic, low-relevance curriculum to a time-pressed attorney.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum includes practical exercises or skills, not just reading
pedagogical.justification: The agent's response consists entirely of diagnostic questions with no practical exercises, skills, or hands-on learning components introduced yet, making it impossible to evaluate practice orientation in the curriculum.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum offers a shortcut or "if time is limited" path for urgent timelines
pedagogical.justification: The agent asks five detailed questions before providing any curriculum, but never offers a minimum viable path or 'if time is limited' shortcut for users with urgent timelines—it only asks about timeline as one of several intake questions without proactively offering an expedited track.

pedagogical.description: Curriculum identifies ongoing sources for staying current after initial learning
pedagogical.justification: The agent has not yet provided any curriculum content, let alone identified ongoing sources for staying current after initial learning — it has only asked intake questions, so this dimension cannot be evaluated positively.

anti_patterns.description: Agent teaches the substantive law rather than creating a learning plan
anti_patterns.justification: The agent asked clarifying questions to gather information needed to build a curriculum, rather than teaching substantive employment law doctrine itself.

anti_patterns.description: Agent recommends a curriculum requiring hundreds of hours for someone with a short timeline
anti_patterns.justification: The agent has not yet recommended any curriculum or time estimates — it is appropriately gathering information about the user's timeline and context before making any recommendations.

anti_patterns.description: Agent fails to include governing statutes, regulations, or key cases
anti_patterns.justification: The agent has not yet built a curriculum — it is gathering requirements before doing so, making it premature to evaluate whether primary legal sources will be included.
